title: Stage 3 cancer patient was left on a trolley in A&E for 16 hours
text:
Stage 3 cancer patient was left on a trolley in A&E for 16 hours Dad-of-three was left in a corridor along with dozens of other seriously ill patients Share Cancer patient Barry Marshall-Everitt was wheeled into A&E and left there for 16 hours (Photo: Steve Bainbridge) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Cancer patient Barry Marshall-Everitt, 69, was left on a trolley in A&E for 16 hours before finally being admitted to a ward. 
Yesterday the 69-year-old, who has stage three uretic cancer, told of his horrific ordeal a fortnight ago at Whittington Hospital, in North London. 
The dad-of-three, former music promoter, said: “Despite four major operations and six weeks’ radiotherapy, the disease has spread like wildfire. Two weeks ago, I was struggling with a raging infection, later diagnosed as sepsis, and within minutes I was being rushed to hospital .” 
As he was wheeled into A&E shortly after 3pm Barry felt “like I was arriving in a medical battleground. The place was heaving and staff didn’t have time for me. I wasn’t even given any painkillers. Read More Shocking footage shows asthma attack toddler lying on cold floor for EIGHT HOURS in A&E Dad-of-three was taken to Whittington Hospital in North London (Photo: www.alamy.com) 
“They put me on a trolley and I was left in a corridor along with dozens of other seriously ill patients. It was freezing and noisy. There were drunks in there and the nurses had to call security.” 
Barry says things finally began to settle down around 6am and someone gave him water and porridge.“In all, it was 16 hours before I was admitted to a ward and given a bed.” 
Barry found the nurses there just as busy as in A&E. “Cancer isn’t pretty. My bandages need changing daily but I went three days with the same dressing. The bandages were sodden. Blood was oozing out. 
“Then on the fourth day I found out I had contracted MRSA. It was a nightmare. Read More "I had routine scan and was told unborn baby had mystery condition - a week later she was stillborn" 
“I feel like I’ve been at the mercy of an NHS in absolute crisis.” 
A spokeswoman for Whittington Health NHS Trust said: “The trust has robust plans in place to manage peaks in A&E demand for the winter months of 2017. 
“We are currently managing unprecedented high demand and this can result in delays for admission for a small number of patients. We would like to apologise for any delays.” 
•Barry’s only hope of a cure is a new £200,000 treatment in America involving radiation and immune therapy. If you would like to make a donation, please visit www.gofundme.com/barrycancerfund Like us on Facebook
